About that Moneth whose name at first begun</br>From great AUGUSTUS, that Romes Empire wonne:</br>When the fierce Dog of Heaven, begun to rise</br>To baite the Lyon in th' Olympian skies.</br>Whose hot fire-breathing influence did cracke</br>With too much heate our aged Grandames backe,</br>Lapping up Rivers with his blaring tongue</br>T' allay the thirst which his proud stomacke stung.</br>Then did each Creature languish pant and beate</br>Under the influence of this horrid heate,</br>And I that oft in my low seated Cell</br>Had felt the burning of his fury fell:</br>Upon a time Aurora shining faire</br>Went forth to take the solace of the ayre.</br>And in those Meades beyond the lofty Towers</br>Of that white Pallace, where the nightly houres</br>Have oft bin spent in sounds of Musicke sweet</br>And active motion of the nimble feet:</br>Where earthly sonnes by night were seene to move,</br>Whilest many hearts were fir'd with flames of Love.</br>There I made choyse to walke before the Sunne</br>Had shewne his face, within our Horizon;</br>But on those bankes by which each turning tide</br>Thames lovely Isis with calme streames doth glide,</br>I had not walked long ere Dayes bright King</br>T' Olympus top his golden Carre did bring:

Whose Steedes with sting of his free lashes driven</br>With such swift speed did gallop through the heaven,</br>That Natures faire productions heere beneath</br>Did seeme to melt under their burning breath,</br>The wing'd inhabitants both of earth and skie</br>That too and fro in th' open ayre did flie</br>To Thickets, Woods, and Groves, swift concourse made</br>To shroud themselues under their leavie shade,</br>The bleating Lambe and little wandring Sheepe</br>That in the open fields before did keepe,</br>Forsaking their free laire, all flocking came</br>To seeke for shelter 'gainst Sol's burning flame.</br>And I 'mongst the rest compeld by heate</br>Which on my head did violently beat</br>To seeke some covert shade straight tooke my way</br>Unto a Grove which neere confining lay.</br>Where when I came the lofty trees, I clad</br>In Summers pride did cast a cooling shade,</br>Under whose leaves from Phoebus burning rayes</br>Sweet birds sate singing their Melodious layes,</br>There sate I downe upon the grassy ground</br>Amid'st those silent shades encompast round</br>By leavy trees that Arbour wise did spread</br>There goodly armes thicke brauncht above my head,</br>But as I there my selfe did closely shroud</br>The chearefull voyce of many laughing loude</br>All suddainely did penetrate myne eare</br>Which did apall my sence with suddaine feare</br>And casting round about my rowling eye</br>Without the wood I chanced to espie</br>A ragged crue of folke all set around</br>About a sunny bancke upon the ground</br>They all were clad in rags of Beggery</br>Taking no karpe of any faculty</br>Or honest calling to rely upon,</br>For trade or true profession had they none;</br>And now to passe the tedious time away</br>With pleasant tales as in the Sunne they lay</br>Each one in course the other did succeed</br>Which much content 'mongst themselves did breed</br>And I to be partaker of their mirth</br>Being closely hidden with a hill of earth</br>Unheard or seene convey'd my selfe so neare</br>That all their chat I un-espied did heare;</br>Some told of battailes and of bloody fights,</br>And some of Ladies and of loves delights</br>And some of dire events and Tragicall</br>And some of Jests and loves sports Comicall:</br>But 'mongst the rout one well I wot there was</br>That all the rest in fluent speech did passe</br>Who with good utterance that became him well</br>A pretty story of an Ape did tell.</br>All which for that it seemeth unto mee</br>Worthy their view whose thoughts delighted bee</br>In morrall discipline I will unfold it</br>And in those tearmes in which the Begger told it.

Not many yeares (quoth he) are past and gone</br>Since heavens faire Virgin in her silver throne</br>From forth her lap such golden blessings threw</br>As if th' old Age againe shee would renew,</br>And at that time the vast worlds Forrest wide</br>Deckt in the Summers coate of Aestas pride</br>Did flourish and growe proude in lusty prime</br>Beneath the Sunne-shine of sweet summers time</br>There many Joviall trees shoot up on high</br>With threatning heads did seeme to vaile the skie</br>Beneath the shade of whose protecting armes</br>The Birds sate singing free from fearefull harmes,</br>The Beasts likewise might all securely goe</br>About the Forrest roaming too and fro,</br>For with the Eagle that skie climing bird</br>And his consorts they late had made accord,</br>And unto peacefull state all things to bring</br>As meete it was they made the Lyon King;</br>And at that season many beasts found grace</br>That liv'd obscure before and in meane place.</br>'Mongst whome a beast that was of Secrops brood</br>Whome of a man Jove in his irefull moode,</br>Detesting his deceitfull guile did make</br>So foule a beast that no man could him take</br>T' have bin a man, yet was it with such skill</br>That being a beast a man he favoured still.</br>His limbes in lesser space then mans are knit</br>Beneath his Eyes his Nose more flat doth sit</br>And like the face which crabbed age doth spill</br>Deepe wrinkles frowne-like his front did fill;</br>There to his Apish limbs are every where</br>Thicke over-growne with sallow coloured haire,</br>And him in land of Apes Ile, Jove did place</br>There to abide and never show his face</br>Amongst us men, where hee not long did stay</br>Ere 'mongst the beasts lewd prankes hee gan to play;</br>For in the golden Age the worlds first spring</br>Even in the pallace of the Forrests King,</br>His witty wiles he oft in practise put</br>Them to deceive, for which his taile was cut;</br>Exiling him for evermore from thence</br>To the Ape Ile againe for his offence.</br>But he that long time there liv'd all a mort</br>His taile being cut, for comming to the Court</br>Of better fortunes now gan cogitate</br>And forth he comes to mend his meane estate,</br>His way unto the Forrest straight he takes</br>And in his journey this observance makes</br>Who liv'd disgracefull, who in favour were</br>And 'bout the Lyon who cheife Place did beare;</br>The golden fleeced Sheepe he first did spie</br>Patterne of patience, and simplicitie</br>Grasing obscurely 'mongst the meaner sort</br>As being a stranger in the Lyons Court;</br>"For who so beares simplicities true badge</br>To live in Princes Courts doe seldome fadge."</br>And though the silly Sheepe contented were</br>For that plaine honest life, which he did beare</br>Yet for his golden Fleece against his will</br>Hee was acquainted with the Courtiers still.</br>Fast by the Sheepe the humble Oxe did graise</br>Who for he sought not his estate to raise,</br>Was held in base contempt for his meeke minde</br>"Meekenesse in Greatnesse we so seldome finde.</br>The Ape being glad to see the Sheepes bad case</br>And plaine simplicity in such disgrace</br>Thought with himselfe as true it was indeed</br>That wily wit would stand him in best steed,</br>And on his way he forth gan wend a pace</br>Hoping at Court to finde such future grace;</br>That in the end he doubted not to bring</br>Himselfe in favour with the Forrest King.</br>Where when he came himselfe he did apply</br>T' observe all fashions with an heedfull eye,</br>The first on whome he any notice tooke</br>Was that high horned beast who in his looke</br>Beares signes apparant of his secret minde</br>To wit the Goat, a lover borne by kinde</br>For he the habit had of all cheife sleights</br>In wanton loves and Ladies Court delights.</br>On which most Gallants now their wits doe prove</br>To serve their Ladies and their Lemmons love.</br>But he surpast them all for he could sing</br>In chaunting songs, and on the warbling string</br>Of Vyoll sweet thereto divinely played</br>The sound of which would charme the chaistest Maide,</br>For which he was of Females so approv'd</br>That they 'bove all the rest him chiefely lov'd;</br>Yet he with whally eyes and shaggy beard</br>And welked hornes so Satir-like appeard</br>That such a grim fac't fellow would affright</br>A lewd Faustinaes selfe in darkest night,</br>Thereto his body did so ranckly smell</br>That he himselfe might not abide it well;</br>But he that fault did hide with pleasing sent</br>Of sweet perfume when ere abroad he went,</br>The Ape him oft beheld in passing by</br>And in his service would his fortune try</br>By meanes made by the Monkey, his neere friend</br>Who on the Goate chiefe servant did attend.</br>But loe not long hee stood thus all a mort,</br>Ere hee beheld at entring of the Court</br>A troupe of Gallants, rushing in the way</br>All proudly clad in strange and rich aray,</br>With wide-big-bason lookes they all did gape</br>In passing by upon the silly Ape.</br>For mickle pride (sull well I wot) they tooke</br>To daunt a stranger with a scornefull looke;</br>Thereto, from fullest mouthes they tooke delight</br>With horrid Oathes, the golden Starres to smite,</br>Ne gave they due regard, or Reverend love</br>Unto the King of Gods the thundring Jove,</br>But all their Paeans consecrated bee</br>To drunken Bacchus on low bended knee.</br>The chiefe 'mongst these that bare supreamest sway</br>Was the fell Bore, who with the least delay</br>Even for a looke misdeem'd, would hazard life</br>In any furious broyle or bloody strife,</br>With him came many Beasts that did delight</br>In sternefull rage, debate, and bloody fight:</br>And therefore loved ever for to bee</br>Together with the Bore in company.</br>There came the Tyger, who withouten dread</br>Was into any danger headlong lead.</br>The wrathfull Beare, whom in his fiery rage</br>Nought else but blood and vengeance might asswage,</br>The Bull and Ram, who both couragious were</br>But wanted wit in fury to forbeare.</br>Amidst this Crew a simple beast there was</br>To Court being newly come, to wit, the Asse,</br>Whom they with fawning speech and threats withall</br>So wrought unto their will, that at their call</br>They had both him and his, and sooth to say</br>Inricht with golden store, hee was fit pray</br>For such in Court whose credit waxed bare,</br>So witlesse was hee and so voyd of care;</br>For he of late had left his Countrey home</br>His Sire being dead, and now to Court was come,</br>Where all a flaunt, hee ryots and consumes</br>In gold, in silver, silke and sweet perfumes</br>His old Sires, ill-got-goods now goes to wracke,</br>Farmes, Forrests, Fields, hee beares upon his backe,</br>And never deemes what Fate will him betide</br>When all is spent by his unseemely pride.

The Ape that had observ'd with heedfull eye</br>The stout demeanour of this Company,</br>Tooke little liking to this kind of life,</br>For hee ne loved for to bee in strife;</br>Ne favour would hee with such perill winne,</br>"But thought best sleeping in the soundest skinne."</br>Long did hee lurke about the Court in vayne,</br>Before his close intent hee could obtayne:</br>"But hee that doth his Fate with heed attend,</br>Seldome but findes good Fortune in the end."</br>And at the last good Fortune being his guide,</br>An old acquaintance he in Court espide;</br>To wit, the Fox, who found in Court such grace</br>That he about the King had gotten place.</br>For the Dread Lyon loathing Luxurie</br>"The Canker-worme of true Nobilitie,"</br>T' allay the pride that in the flesh beares sway</br>And banish loathsome Idlenesse away:</br>To spend his golden houres did still devise</br>In Kingly pastime and faire exercise,</br>There to rich guifts, Prince-like he gave to those,</br>That did themselves to exercise dispose;</br>Thereby to purge his Court to ease inclin'd,</br>And base sloath banish from the Noble mind.</br>In which the Fox, his Soveraigne did so please,</br>Seeming the common Enemie of ease:</br>That hee himselfe in mickle grace did bring</br>With the bold Lyon, his dread Lord and King.</br>But hee foule Carle (not as his King) did make</br>This use of exercise for vertues sake,</br>But gave himselfe thereto with this intent</br>To creepe in favour with foule blandishment</br>To him the Ape in humble manner came</br>To scrape acquaintance and make knowne his name;</br>But the proud Fox, though him hee well did know,</br>Like a true Courtier gan himselfe to show</br>With Elboe pride, and cast of scornfull eye</br>Hee stoutly stalk't upon his tiptoes high</br>Disdaining to th' Apes words to lend his eare</br>Though hee of yore his old acquaintance were.</br>And in such proud contempt he passed by,</br>That the Apes former hopes began to dye;</br>Being in despaire his meane estate to mend</br>Forsaken thus of his old fellow friend.

But the slye Fox advising all this while</br>How the Ape being wittie, prompt, and full of guile,</br>"And that two working wits will soone prevaile</br>In any plot when one may chance to faile;"</br>Straight sends unto the Ape and greets him well,</br>Bidding him come to him his case to tell.</br>The forlorne Ape being almost in despaire</br>With double diligence did make repaire</br>Unto the Fox, to whom obeysance made</br>These famous words in humble wise hee said.

All haile (grave Sir) quoth hee, good fates attend</br>Your steps in Court, still Fortune be your freind</br>And in sweet showers, th' auspicious heav'ns down-shed</br>Their bounteous blessings on your reverent head.

The Fox him thanking, answered in this sort,</br>But say (Sir Ape) what wind brings you to Court?</br>Seemes you have lived in some barren place</br>And want lifes needements for to doe you grace;</br>For you be growne so meager leane and wan,</br>That scarce your legs your limbs upholden can.</br>For which, I weene, you want that wonted wit</br>And judgement sharpe, that seem'd of yore to sit</br>In th' ilke same head, by which you could at need</br>Both helpe your selfe and stand your freind in steed.

Ah mee (Sir Reynald) sayd the wretched Ape</br>Of all the Forrest hardest is my hap</br>That I unhappy wretch, thus as you see</br>Am made the scorne of other beasts to bee;</br>Yet ne'rthelesse Sir, if of your grace you please</br>You of your bounty may my fortunes ease,</br>And set my wit in the old working way</br>"Want of imployment makes best wits decay."

Now certes (said the Fox) yee say right well,</br>"For custome doth in power so excell;</br>That vertues selfe in the most liberall minde</br>For want of it oft times decay'd we find</br>And use being common made in usefull things</br>Vice to inseperable habit brings."</br>Then pitty t'were, so ripe a wit you have</br>The want of good imploiment should deprave.</br>Read then, Sir Ape, what course you doe intend</br>And if in it my helpe may you befriend:</br>Doubt not to find for old acquaintance sake</br>My furtherance in any course you take.

To this the Ape, deepe sighing, thus did say</br>Ah (noble Sir) y blessed be this day,</br>That with such hap good fortune did me greet</br>As with your selfe so happily to meet;</br>For well I weene, I onely hope to rise</br>By sage instruction of your sound devise.</br>Then read (faire Sir) of favour I you pray</br>What custome in the Court now beares cheife sway</br>To what thing most is that Heroicke mind</br>Of our dread Soveraigne chiefely now enclind,</br>"For well I wot the subiect that will bring</br>Himselfe in favour with his Lord and King,</br>What his Lord likes at least must seeme to love</br>And of his fancy must alwayes approve."

Surely, said Reynald, this which you have spoken</br>Of your grave judgement gives sufficient token,</br>And know, that now the Lyons chiefe delight</br>Is to behold those that in nimble fight,</br>Can best pursue the wilder beasts in chase</br>And such as they be now in speciall grace;</br>For he with idle ease may not away</br>The obstacle to vertues best assay.</br>And therefore least good dayes may be mispent</br>To noble exercise he still is bent:</br>Ne doe I doubt but you by pregnant wit</br>To any exercise your selfe can fit,</br>And though of footmanship you be not slow</br>Yet none amongst the best of beasts I know</br>In all the woods with you compar'd may bee</br>For nimblenes and swift Agility.</br>By which you may in frowning Fates despight</br>Purchase you favor in your Soveraignes sight.

Ah (deere Sir) said the Ape, yblessed be</br>Your life with length of dayes for Charitie</br>To me poore wretch.  But say Sir, I you pray</br>By what step shall I make my best assay</br>To gaine the Forests King unto my friend</br>"A good beginning makes a happy end."

To this the Fox replyed, Sir Ape, said hee</br>Well have you said, yet that my busines bee</br>Meane while your wits for my imployment frame</br>For in the Forrest wee will find good game.</br>"Let Drudges by base toile there living get</br>The generous borne will onely live by wit;"</br>This said, the subtle Fox in secret wise</br>The Ape gan counsell with such sound advise</br>That in short space in Court he got much grace</br>When those of more desert could find no place.</br>"For few there be, that for good guifts of mind</br>Or vertues bare regard doe favour find</br>Onely they rise that can by guilefull wit</br>Serve their owne turne with gainefull benefit,</br>The honest mind from thence is made to flye</br>When shamelesse ribaulds are advanced high</br>The simple-hearted are accounted base,</br>When bold and impudent are most in grace,</br>Vaine boasting Thrasoes, soothing Flatterers,</br>Sly cogging Gnatoes, secret whisperers,</br>Tale-bearing Fleerers, and false accusing lackes,</br>There beare best shewes upon their golden backes."</br>'Mongst whom the Ape did beare himselfe so well</br>That hee in rich attire did farre excell;</br>And eke his sides with flesh so filled were,</br>That not a bone did any where appeare.</br>Ne, few him knew that knew him well before</br>T' have bin the wretched Ape he was of yore,</br>For never more did Proteus change his shape;</br>For to deceive, then did this wilie Ape</br>At first with lowly lookes and humble minde,</br>Himselfe in great States favour he did winde,</br>With Sycophantlike trickes, hee tooke delight,</br>With every Jacke to play the Parasite,</br>To sooth, to cogge, to fawne, to lye, to sweare,</br>To crouch, to glose, and patiently to beare</br>All grosse abuse, to take up every word</br>Falne from the lying lippes of some great Lord:</br>To laugh, looke sad, to like and dislike both,</br>To say and unsay, sweare and forsweare troth.</br>But when by humble service and long suite</br>In Court hee came to bee of some repute,</br>Hee many subtle sleights did quickly find</br>T' exhalt himselfe when others came behind:</br>Then waxt hee proud, and bent his guilefull wit</br>To turne all things to his owne benefit;</br>False of his faith, yet prodigall in word,</br>Darke in his talke, yet seldome would afford</br>Poore Suitors hearing; but unlesse they came</br>With golden warrants signed for the same:</br>Yet if that Suitors meanes for suites would use,</br>Whom better, then Sir Ape, could any chuse;</br>For many a Canker-worme of common state</br>Some farming Huckster, or Sea runagate,</br>T' increase their private good by publique ill,</br>Might through his helpe with ease obtaine their will.</br>Thus the slye Ape with naturall wit endow'd,</br>Grew great in wealth, by wealth grew wondrous proud.</br>"For costly wealth even to the basest wight</br>Gives golden wings to soare a lofty flight."

Now while the Ape did study more and more</br>By daily begging to increase his store,</br>The Fox that idle was, but by his wit</br>For the Apes turne still layd foundation fit,</br>And on a time I weene, above the rest,</br>To th' Ape hee commeth with a merry Jest.</br>(Sir Ape) quoth hee, if you my friend will stand,</br>Wee will not want t' have gold at our command;</br>For I in Court have found a gallant gull</br>Whom of his gold, (of which hee yet is full)</br>We well may fleece, if you will lend your ayde</br>To which in hast, the Ape this answer made.
Say in good sooth, Sir Reynald, I you pray,</br>In what my word and deed you helpen may</br>And of what Mister wight make you report</br>I know him not?  spends he his dayes in Court?

Yes, quoth the Fox, to Court he came of late</br>And well I wot hee is a Jolly mate;</br>It is to wit, the Asse, whose aged syre</br>Did toyle himselfe and drudge for daily hyre</br>And left his thrifty gaine unto his sonne</br>To gentilize it here when he was gone.

Sayd then the Ape, foule shame such fooles betide</br>That to maintayne their sonnes unthrifty pride</br>Will bow their labouring backes and take no pleasure</br>For all their paines upon their hardrackt treasure.

The Fox reply'd, you seeme to bee a Foe</br>To gentle kinde; for if it were not so,</br>How should the Forrest in a moment space,</br>Breed so much gentle-blood of meaner race,</br>And sooth to say, this Asse though meanely borne</br>Yet through much wealth, made wondrous full of scorn.

An humour strange in his conceit doth feed</br>That by discent hee comes of Noble breed.</br>It was my chance the other day to be</br>With th' horned Goate, and him in company,</br>Who both were clad in goodly rich array:</br>But in attire, the Asse was farre more gay.</br>His head with plume of Feathers was bedight,</br>His trappings all with Bells and Bosses bright</br>Was richly furnished, which with more pride</br>Hung downe unto the ground on eyther side.</br>These lustie Gallants to increase their fame,</br>In their conceits at Knighthood both doth ayme.</br>Which if for them wee can by friends obtayne,</br>Wee shall not fayle for meed t' have double gayne;</br>For the Asse so vaine appeares, that he will give</br>His whole estate, ere he unknighted live.</br>And for the Goate, we shall have golden fee</br>Of Female kind, that they may Ladyed bee.</br>Being dub'd by him; Say then (Sir Ape) I pray</br>Good gaine is oft times lost by long delay.

Sir Reynald, said the Ape, my forward mind</br>Brookes no delay, where I a meane may find</br>To worke my will:  but know that your intent</br>Makes me much doubt, the sequell of th' event:</br>For this high Order is to those assign'd,</br>That famous be for vertue of the mind,</br>Or for some high atchivement; for their meed</br>Have purchas'd it, to glorifie their deed.</br>How may we then bring such a thing to passe,</br>As purchase Knighthood for the golden Asse.

Tush, quoth the Fox, the world now doth not see</br>The thing that is, but that which seemes to bee.</br>And hee whose tongue the tayle of Greatnesse lickes</br>If he will thrive, his Conscience never stickes</br>To overgild, and lift up to the skies</br>With deepest oathes, inventions blackest lyes;</br>And that we may our purpose bring to passe,</br>We must obscure the folly of the Asse.</br>The vertues rare that beautifie his mind,</br>Wee must applaud, thereby the world to blind;</br>And say and sweare, that hee amongst the best</br>Of all the Forrest is the hopeful'st beast;</br>So to the world they both shall seeme to bee</br>For vertues sake, much worthy this degree.

Now certes, said the Ape, this is good leasing</br>And to the Lyon it will sure bee pleasing:</br>When in the Forrest hee shall heare the fame,</br>Which in their high applause wee can proclaime.</br>Meane time, Sir Reynald, backe returne with speed</br>Unto them both, and tell them 'tis decreed,</br>That worthy they shall weare the golden Spurre</br>Like two true sonnes of Mars, and ne're incurre</br>The hazard of the Field, but onely this,</br>To have our fee before, we may not misse.

Tush, quoth the Fox, bee confident in mee,</br>A foole hee is that will behind hand bee:</br>If that our purpose have but good event</br>The gaine is ours, neere thinke your paines mispent.</br>This said, themselves they both began t' apply</br>T' effect their purpose, all their friends they try;</br>And such applauses daily they impute</br>To the Asse and Goat, for whom they make this suite</br>That in the end both twaine in pompe and pride</br>Were dubd Knights errand, of the Forrest wide</br>Of whom in guerdon of their mickle paines</br>The begging Ape and Fox had golden gaines,</br>So both thinke well themselves apayd to bee</br>They with their Knighthood, th' other with their Fee.</br>But let not such base Lossels that account</br>All merit vayne, and onely hope to mount</br>Themselves with golden wings to such degree</br>That seeke to purchase it with baser Fee;</br>And thinke a silver silken vestiment</br>A gilded Spurre, or strange acoutrement</br>The fruits of brainsicke fancies fond delight</br>The onely meanes to make a perfect Knight.</br>Let not such dunghil brood of Kestrill kinde</br>That unto honour never cast their minde</br>Dismay the noble spirit that assayes</br>Through deeds of Armes his name on high to raise;</br>For bare degrees that want true vertues merit</br>Shall in fames golden booke no place inherit.</br>When Honour, Meede, and noble vertues praise</br>In Swan-white age findes fresh and youthfull dayes;</br>Then let not fond Sir Asse, disgracefull seeme</br>To those that for their worth and high esteeme</br>In vertues bare regard exalted bee</br>By Princes grace to place of such degree;</br>Let boasting Bragadochioes of our time</br>And golden-handed Churles, that seeke to clime</br>To places of such high credit, inly burne</br>And with the vaine Sir Asse, the Begger spurne;</br>So shall the Ape their follies still deride</br>And fleece their store for their aspiring pride.</br>Who tasting once the sweet delights that came</br>By this his Begging trade, himselfe did frame</br>With golden fees of dayly Begging base,</br>Shame light on gaine got with so foule disgrace;</br>Yet shamelesse hee continued begging still</br>To glut the gulfe of his unsatiate will.</br>Which many noble beasts did soone espie</br>On whome the Lyons safetie did relye,</br>To whose great wisdome and fore-casting cares</br>Committed were the Forrests cheife Affaires.</br>But 'mongst them all, that most illustrate beast</br>That worthy Counsellor from heav'n yblest,</br>The noble Elephant tooke speciall heed</br>That out of Court such Beggers he might weed.</br>And sooth to say, as Greekes doe well recite</br>With crooked Trumpet he could truely write,</br>And by the working of his prudent mind</br>Could oft obscure the wits of humaine kind;</br>For on his care the Kingdomes happines</br>Did most depend, and for her worthines</br>To him committed was in custodie</br>The keeping of the common Treasurie.</br>This worthy Peere, who dayly did behold</br>The shamelesse begging of these Beggers bold</br>In wisedome divers wayes did cast about</br>To finde the wily Apes foule knavery out.</br>But th' Ape so well him bore that long it was</br>E're th' Elephant could bring his will to passe;</br>Meane time like as the Leach upon the store</br>From greedy sucking ne're desists, before</br>The place be bloodlesse left exhausted dry</br>So did th' Ape to th' Asse himselfe apply.

For when the doultish beast ycleped was</br>Through all the Court (by name of hight Sir Asse)</br>Puft uppe with pride, he thought himselfe to bee</br>The fairest beast that ever eye did see,</br>Hee learned had to praunce with stately pace</br>To rayne his Asses head with lofty grace</br>And in each point himselfe so high to beare</br>As if that hee some noble Palfray were;</br>Which pride of his, was laughed so to scorne</br>Of every beast that knew him to bee borne</br>Of base descent, yet hee through want of wit</br>Swolne proud by wealth, such folly did commit,</br>That he their common Gull accounted was</br>And bore the title of the golden Asse.

Which th' Ape did well perceive, and with vaine showes</br>Of fained friendship gan with him to glose,</br>With soothing tongue his folly he did feed</br>And gave him counsell by some glorious deed</br>To amplify his name in every place,</br>Hee knew he was not come of Asses race;</br>But racher sprung of some such noble breed</br>As swift wing'd Pegasus that heav'nly Steed.</br>Hee wisht him therefore in a single race</br>To chalenge th' Horse, thereby to get him grace</br>Ne did he doubt but he should win the day</br>If hee with courage bold but gave th' Assay.

Sir Asse, with selfe conceit being mov'd in minde</br>To heare his praise, forgot himselfe by kinde</br>T' have bin an Asse, and in this humour sent</br>A chalenge to the Horse with this intent,</br>To runne with him before the Forrest King</br>In hope himselfe in favour for to bring.</br>The day was set and chosen was the place</br>Upon the open Plaine to runne this race;</br>Where the dread King of beasts stood to behold</br>The stout Sir Asse, performe his chalenge bold;</br>The time being come forth came the lustie Horse</br>With comely grace to runne th' expected course,</br>Who by his stately gesture gan to show</br>Stout signes in proud contempt of his base foe.</br>His crested necke hee often bow'd to ground</br>With foaming mouth as if he would confound</br>The earth at once, and from his nosthrils came</br>A fierie breath as from a furnace flame;</br>His pricking Eares stood startling on his head</br>And of a common custome inlye bred,</br>In jollity of pride which did abound,</br>His hollow hoofe still played upon the ground;</br>At last from his strong necke in neighing shrill</br>With sound thereof the Forrest hee did fill,</br>Seeming thereby to call upon Sir Asse,</br>That in this challenge the appellant was.</br>Who vainely vaunting with a gallant trayne</br>Came proudly prauncing on the ample Plaine;</br>Where when hee came beholding well the Horse</br>His comely grace, brave shape, and wondrous force:</br>Halfe in despaire hee did himselfe repent</br>Of his proud challenge and bold hardiment.

Yet with the vayne applause of flattering mates</br>Being proudly prickt, with Courage bold he waites,</br>The time appointed to begin the race</br>Before the Forrest King being then in place;</br>The signe once given, Sir Asse, began to runne</br>With greedy hope great fame thereby t' have wonne.</br>But the brave Horse in pace away did goe</br>Like winged shaft shot from a Tuscan bowe,</br>Or like a Swallow in the welkin bright</br>That sheeres the subtle ayre with nimble flight,</br>Leaving the sluggish Asse with shame behind</br>To know himselfe to be an Asse by kind.</br>With mickle laughter bred in every place</br>Amongst the beasts that stood to see the race,</br>Which the Ape did well observe with slye intent</br>As he that knew, what would be the event;</br>For when the Asse, amongst the better sort</br>Was held in base contempt throughout the Court,</br>And left forlorne for his stupidity</br>The Ape alone, did keepe him company.</br>Whose doltish nature by his cunning wit</br>In all his actions done he did so fit,</br>That in the end by craft and cousening slye</br>Hee gull'd the simple beast and suckt him dry.</br>Who left forlorne returned all a mort</br>Unto his Country home, from Princes Court.</br>There helpelesse to bewaile in wofull wise</br>His lavish will and wanton riotize;</br>O wretched end of idle vanity,</br>Of misexpence and Prodigality.</br>You younger wits that spend your golden houres,</br>Your selves and substance in great Princes bowers;</br>That quaffe downe Court delights, and dayly swill</br>The seeming sugred Nectar of your ill;</br>That weare your large left patrimonies bare</br>In Drinke, in Dice, Dauncing and dainty fate.</br>That up and downe in Antick shapes doe jet,</br>And on your golden backs doe beare your debt,</br>And with a vaine bewitching hope struck blind</br>Of idle fame doe watch to catch the wind,</br>Yet thinke your selves all others to surpasse</br>In reaching wit.  Behold this forlorne Asse,</br>Who 'mongst the best, once jolly blithe and trim</br>In deepest waves of sweet delight did swim;</br>Now of his golden good he being bereft</br>And driven home, when scarce no home was left:</br>In stead of stately bower, where he had bin</br>An homely Cottage gladly enters in.</br>Where with sad sighes his wretched eyes doe fill</br>In stead of Arras and sweet paintings skill,</br>Upon the broken roofe and slender walls</br>Sticks smoakie black and Spiders dusty coales,</br>In stead of sweet perfumes, the bitter smoake</br>With foggy clouds his tender sight doth choake,</br>In stead of Silver plate, or purest Glasse</br>Hee with the Beggers dish now pleased was,</br>In which for Wine to glad his wofull hart</br>Hee takes cold Whey and water in good part,</br>His Courtly dyet fraught with many a dish</br>Of divers kindes of dainty Flesh and Fish,</br>Is now become the almes of some good house</br>Or homely morsell of some hungry Mouse.</br>The ground his board, greene grasse his Carpet makes</br>And for his Bed a pad of Straw he takes</br>In which distresse, by his owne folly bred</br>Hee weeps, he sighes, and shakes his wofull head;</br>Blaming his bitter Fate, but all in vaine</br>Since of his wealthy store naught doth remaine.</br>Meane time the Ape that liv'd upon his losse</br>Seeing the wretched fortune of the Asse,</br>Did laugh to scorne his wofull misery</br>And pitch'd his nets with fraud and subtilty;</br>To circumvent the weake and simple sort</br>That used to frequent the Princes Court.</br>But thus while th' Ape such things to passe did bring</br>About the pallace of the Forrest King</br>The greedy Wolfe his part did also play</br>In woods abroad t' obtaine his wished pray,</br>Who was a bloudy beast of wicked brood</br>And sought to live by spoyle of others good.</br>Yet had hee large possessions of his owne,</br>And in the woods was mighty wealthy growne,</br>Whereby he daily sought in Cruell wise</br>Upon the poorer Beasts to Tyrannize,</br>The Woods in Common, and th' adjoyning Plaine</br>Hee did convert unto his private gaine;</br>And meaner beasts that nigh his Den did dwell,</br>Hee from their owne abodes did oft expell.</br>'Mongst whom the Urchin and the Squirrill hight,</br>By the Apes helpe, he robbed of their right:</br>For in close thicket farre from sight of Sunne</br>Where in his darksome Den the Wolfe did wonne,</br>The industrious Urchin in his little Cell,</br>Not farre from thence alone did chance to dwell.</br>At whose good hap the Wolfe did much repine</br>And daily did behold with envious eyne,</br>How he in sharpest Winter did enjoy</br>The fruites of Sommers toyle without annoy;</br>For when Pomona did in winters scorne</br>The Woods greene heads with golden fruit adorne,</br>When fields doe seem to laugh, when flowers doe spring</br>When Beasts doe play, and Birds doe sweetly sing;</br>Then would the Urchin watch with curious eye,</br>When Boreas blasts did cuffe the Clouds in skye</br>And shake the Tree when like thicke showers of raine</br>The Fruit would fall, the which with mickle paine</br>Upon his brisled backe, the Urchin bore</br>Home to his Cell to make his winters store,</br>Whereby from winters thrall hee liv'd secure,</br>When other Beasts much sorrow did endure.</br>Now at the entry of the sterne Wolfes denne</br>The place of his abode had long time bin;</br>That 'gainst the State nought could be done or sayd,</br>But by the Urchin it might bee bewrayed.</br>The Wolfe likewise out of his greedy moode</br>Did seeke t' inlarge the place of his abode,</br>By proud incroaching of that little Cell</br>In which his neighbour, th' Urchin us'd to dwell;</br>Wherefore hee sought by death or some disgrace,</br>To dispossesse the Urchin of that place.</br>And on a time from home as th' Urchin went</br>Abroad into the Forrest with intent</br>As was his wont, to get such labours meed,</br>As Fortune in the Forrest had decreed.</br>Loe in the way the tavening Wolfe did watch</br>This silly beast within his pawes to catch,</br>Whom he did often thinke to make his prey,</br>Yet durst hee not at that time give th' Assay,</br>So well the Urchin did his body arme</br>With coate of proofe, 'gainst all intended harme.</br>The Wolfe therefore perceiving force to faile</br>Did seeke by flattering falshood to prevaile.</br>For in the way finding occasion meet</br>With fawning words, thus th' Urchin hee did greet.
Now neighbour, quoth the Wolfe, you be well met</br>Upon what high atchievement be you set,</br>That you thus armed bee, seemes you doe stand</br>In dangers doubt, and feare some harme at hand.

Nay certes, quoth the Urchin, nought I feare</br>Of harme t' ensue, this armed coate I weare</br>For no such cause; but that with paine I may</br>Upon my brisled hide, such fruit convay</br>To my poore home, which in the woods I find,</br>Least with the sluggard unto ease inclin'd,</br>On Summers pleasure I doe fondly feed,</br>And want in Winter to sustaine my need.

The Wolfe replyed, y blessed be thy paine</br>And labour, that deserves to reape good gaine;</br>Yet let me now disswade thee to disarme</br>Thy selfe this once, and feare no future harme,</br>This day desist from toyle and goe with mee</br>Unto our friend, where wee will welcome bee;</br>For to all Beasts, this day is by the Bore</br>Kept festivall, where we shall finde good store</br>Of divers dainty Fruits, of which at will</br>Withouten labour thou mayest have thy fill.</br>This sayd, he used such kinde courtesie</br>Mix'd with such friendly Importunitie;</br>That the poore Urchin, thought his meaning good</br>And would with him unto the neighbouring Wood,</br>Whereas the Bore should wonne; but loe at need</br>A friend was by, to helpe him at that steed.</br>And sure the silly Urchin that same day</br>Unto the Ravening Wolfe had beene a prey,</br>But that the Squirrill from the leavie Tree,</br>Unseene to them the Wolfes intent did see;</br>Who to the Urchin, call'd with loude exclaime;</br>Fond foole said hee, what madnes is this same?</br>How darest thou credit that same cruell Beast,</br>That on thy Carkasse seekes to make his Feast.</br>Take heed, by his seducements bee not led,</br>If thou disarme thy selfe thou art but dead.</br>For hence I did behold how in the way</br>In secret covert hid, hee lurking lay,</br>And hadst thou not with stiffe quill'd pointed hide</br>Beene arm'd about; by him thou sure hadst dy'd.
The Urchin hearing this, upon his chin</br>Did set his feet and drew his brisled skin</br>About his body round, as any ball</br>To shield himselfe, and shun his fatall fall.

Which when the Wolfe perceiv'd, hee went his way</br>Inrag'd in minde, and vow'd without delay</br>To act a swift revenge upon them both,</br>And for his cause, unto the Ape he goeth;</br>To whom, Complaint against them he doth bring</br>To be preferr'd unto the Forrests King.</br>Hee told, how th' Urchin like a theevish wight</br>Did steale abroad in dead of darksome night,</br>Using to sucke the full-fed Kine unkept,</br>While the poore Neatheard all securely slept:</br>And how the Squirrill to augment his store,</br>Did rob the Forrest of the Fruit it bore;</br>And to his will, that he might better shape</br>The greedy fancy of the Begging Ape,</br>Hee wish'd him begge the forfeit of their Goods,</br>Since none amongst the Beasts about the woods</br>There was, with whom such treasure could be found</br>As with them twaine which chiefly did abound</br>With Nuts, and Aples, which the Wolfe could tell</br>Above all things, the Ape lov'd wondrous well.</br>And sooth to say these tidings did so please</br>Th' Apes greedy humor, that with little ease</br>The Wolfe obtain'd his wish for in small space</br>The Urchin and the Squirrill wanting grace</br>Of friends to backe their cause were from those Woods</br>Exil'd for aye, and forfeited there goods;</br>Whereby the Wolfe possession did obtaine</br>Of th' Urchins little Cell, and th' Ape did gaine</br>By begging Nuts and Aples which of yore</br>By others paines were hoarded up in store.</br>Thus dayly did the subtile Ape obtaine</br>Pleasure and profit both withouten paine,</br>By which I weene compar'd to all the rest</br>"Amongst all Craftsmen Beggers are the best:"</br>For ev'n the proud'st that thinkes paines taking's base</br>To turne oft Begger thinkes it no disgrace.</br>But whilest the Ape lull'd in security</br>Did swim in pleasures and felicity</br>Not wanting ought, for seldome did he crave</br>The guift of ought but he the same might have,</br>The noble Elephant that in the Court</br>Did beare chiefe sway amongst the supreame sort</br>Like a true Statesman, for the Forrest good</br>Against the Apes incessant begging stood.</br>Whereby the Ape did stoope his gallant minde</br>For though by information he might finde</br>Ought worthy begging, yet the Princes grant</br>Hee did not crave; because by th' Elephant</br>Oft to revoke his grant the King was mov'd</br>If to the state it prejudiciall stood;</br>Therefore the Ape that liv'd before secure</br>And thought his golden begging would endure</br>For ever certaine:  with a heavy cheere</br>Now hung the head; for well it did appeare</br>Hee might goe swinke and sweat to get his living</br>Since that the Forrest Prince did cease from giving,</br>Sir Reynald likewise that same crafty mate</br>That did in the Apes beg'd guifts participate</br>Now wanted meanes, whereby he might support</br>His bravery 'mongst the gallants of the Court</br>For long he watched had and cast about</br>By his fine wit to finde some purchase out</br>Some ancient Ruine of Antiquitie</br>Or ought that might be tearm'd inutilie,</br>But naught he found that in the Forrest stood</br>That was inutilie for common good,</br>Which when he did perceive:  halfe in despaire</br>Unto the Ape his friend he made repaire</br>Who to each other often though in vaine</br>Their sad mishap in secret did complaine.</br>Yet in the end the Fox did finde a fetch</br>"For dire constraint, the wit at large doth stretch,"</br>Hee well remembred that if any beast</br>Were found offensive to the Kings beheast</br>Or did infringe the Law through all the Woods</br>By penall statutes lost both Lands and goods,</br>The which without controle, as lawfull gaine</br>Th' Ape for a boone by begging might obtaine,</br>This once being thought upon the wily Ape</br>As carefull of their good this speech shape.

Sir Reynald (said the Ape) wee be in case</br>To be undone unlesse by Joves good grace</br>Against the storme, in time we doe provide</br>"Time runnes away and no man stayes the tide."</br>You see that wee be needy and in lacke</br>And in the Court, the eyes of every Jacke</br>Are fix'd upon us, and these garments old</br>Cannot in Court our countenance long uphold.</br>Then say (Sir Reynald) as yee be right wise</br>What hopefull course for us can you devise</br>Wee must provide for helpe without delay</br>Or hopelesse leave the Court and runne away.

The Fox reply'd full little did I weene</br>That in this case so witlesse you had beene</br>So long as hope remaines; why should wee doubt</br>Have wee not working wit to cast about,</br>Then have good hope, for wee in little space</br>Will worke our selves againe in Fortunes grace,</br>We know right well the Oxe and silly Sheepe</br>Though they themselves from Court in private keepe</br>As being but rusticke Chuffes of base account</br>Yet they in wealthy substance farre surmount</br>Whom if by subtilty we can but draw</br>Within the compasse of the Princes law</br>To stop our mouthes we shall have golden fee</br>So much they feare in danger for to bee.</br>And if this faile; yet we upon our oath</br>As loyall subjects can appeach them both</br>For speaches spoken 'gainst the Government</br>Or other trespasse, which we can invent,</br>Which that wee may to better purpose bring</br>We can disgus'd, talke of the Forrest King</br>And aske what tydings in the Princes Court</br>What vice in common they doe most support</br>And in their speech if we them tripping take</br>Wee by addition can the matter make</br>To seeme farre worse; by which if they i' th' end</br>Convicted bee; then that which we intend,</br>Wee have obtayn'd; for we their goods have wonne</br>In recompence of our good service done.</br>This said, the Ape approving Reynald wit</br>In that hee at a pinch, could helpe with it</br>With speed in some strange habit, both disgis'd</br>Would put in practise what hee had devis'd.</br>They both agreed themselves forthwith to clad</br>Like stranger Countrymen of late decayed;</br>Whose habit and demeanor had you seene</br>You would have though the wretched Ape t' have been</br>Some sturdie Clowne that late had left the Carre</br>And in this strange disguise had come from farre,</br>Hee was y clad all in a Russet gray</br>Of coursest stuffe, yet with such meane aray,</br>He seemed well appay'd as did appeare</br>Being well contented with his Countrey weare,</br>His russet Jerkin, many yeares y worne</br>Was waxen bare, and at the elboes torne:</br>His Breeches of the same made scanty wise</br>So close did sit unto his brawny thighes,</br>That his fat flankes that plumpe and jolly were,</br>Like two round Balls did through the same appeare;</br>Thereto, his blew round Cap him well became</br>With a plume Feather pendant on the same,</br>Which o' th' one side of his head he ever wore</br>As if in minde some high conceit hee bore.</br>A rusty Sword hee carryed by his side</br>And at his backe a Dagger well ytide,</br>For many hackes therein made long agoe</br>Sufficient proofes did of the mettall show,</br>His woollen Hose were of the purest white</br>Of thicke strong knit, and yet in open sight</br>Were broken 'bove the heeles, and both his Shooes</br>Worne with long travell out about the toes.</br>And thus he travayl'd with his fellow Foxe</br>About the Forrest for to finde the Oxe,</br>And silly Sheepe, whom the Ape had first espide</br>In Field farre off, fast by the River side,</br>And said unto the Foxe; Behold I see</br>In yon same field, where they both grasing bee:</br>Now prove your wit Sir Reynald, if you can,</br>Begin you first, you are the graver man.</br>This sayd, they came where th' Oxe and Sheepe did grase,</br>Whom thus the Foxe did greet with fawning phrase;</br>All haile (Sir Oxe) said hee, full glad am I</br>To see you beare your lofty head so high,</br>It seemes to us by this your goodly port</br>You are in favour in the Princes Court,</br>You can informe us of some tidings there</br>And 'bout the Lyon who chiefe place doth beare.

"The Oxe reply'd, (good Sir) you deeme amisse</br>For your conjecture goes astray in this,</br>Seeing Courtly favour is no cause that I</br>Seeme thus to beare my branched head so hie,</br>But humble thoughts, which wounded harts doe heale</br>In sweet content, is cause of all weale,</br>Pale envy poyson to the Statesmans good</br>Nere gnawes my heart ne suckes my vitall blood,</br>Nor greedy Avarice of others shares</br>Disturbes my sweet content with boundlesse cares;</br>These pastures bounds my thoughts doe ever bound,</br>Ne doe I joy to feed in stranger ground,</br>But with my Fate suffic'd I still abide</br>Not fearing any ill that may betide,</br>Of Musickes rarest skill I take no keepe</br>At any time to summon timely sleepe,</br>But sweet voyc'd Birds, and milde Streames gently gushes</br>My wear, limbes, in restfull quiet Hushes.</br>The often horrid sounds of Court Alarmes</br>Ne're startle me from sleepe for feare of harmes,</br>But sleeping till the morne secure of feares,</br>The Birds sing sweet Bon-jours about mine eares:</br>Thus live I happy in content of minde,</br>Which wee in Courtly greatnesse seldome finde."

Certes, said the Ape, it seemes yee be right wise</br>That can of worldly weale so well advise,</br>And yet in this me seemes you have digrest,</br>For 'mongst the best you being a goodly beast</br>To great advancement, may your selfe soone bring</br>And authorize high Service for the King.

"Alas, (quoth th' Oxe) How vulgar is affection</br>In vainely seeking after fond promotion,</br>As well th' Ignoble as the Noble blood</br>Deeme vading pompe the happie mans chiefe good.</br>Yet view the Court and marke the misery</br>Of those that swim in Court felicitie,</br>Whose wretched steps in Princes Court attends</br>His slavish will on others wills depends,</br>His turn-coat thoughts more light then lightest feather</br>Turn'd with the winde and return'd with the weather</br>Ev'n as his Masters changing humour is,</br>Must turne and Change to like of that or this</br>Against his Conscience, praise impietie,</br>And sooth foule sinne with fawning flatterie.</br>And yet suppose thou shouldst exalted bee</br>To some place past Court-crouching with the knee,</br>And by the helpe of Greatnesse finde such grace</br>As neere the steps of Maiestie t' have place,</br>Yet marke (fond foole) and see what unseene woe</br>Would follow thee though thou in Gold shouldst goe,</br>To bee a Partner in the Privitie</br>And close concealement of Authoritie,</br>Though to thy second selfe thou shew the same</br>Oft winnes thee Death, and never dying shame;</br>Yet in thy Conscience to conceale such things</br>When life is gone, Death worse then death it brings.</br>Oh then how blest and happy a wight is hee</br>That lives from Court though nere so base he bee."

T' enlarge this Theame the Sheepe did silence breake,</br>"Deare neighbor Oxe (quoth he) the truth you speake,</br>Yet more then this, doe many undergoe</br>That in the Court doe make a goodly show,</br>For many there that beare so bold a face</br>And deeme all vulgars beggerly and base,</br>That strut on Tiptoe, and with Elboe pride</br>Aspire to reach the square from side to side,</br>Oft stoope their gallant mindes and prove I weene,</br>Worse Beggers farre then those that Beggers beene;</br>With fawning tongue and Court eclipsing guile</br>They claw the Great in vices more then vile,</br>And then of this or that in daily begging,</br>They still sollicite them with tedious gaping.</br>But loe alas, what proves this hardracket store</br>Got by encroaching on the pined poore.</br>Lifes bitter curse, while heere on Earth wee dwell</br>And Soules sad burthen bearing downe to Hell.</br>Why then doe those that tediously importune</br>The royall Lyon to advance their Fortune,</br>Thus base and Begger-like sollicite still</br>T' increase their profit by a generall ill:</br>They knew the noble Lyons Royall minde</br>To humble Suitors is by nature kinde,</br>Nor stearne nor statefull to the Subjects base,</br>But full of Lenitie and Gentle grace.</br>They know hee strives by his benignitie</br>To imitate the Gods in charitie,</br>Which they will still abuse, being Begger-lipt,</br>Till from his Court such Beggers base be whipt,"</br>This speech so toucht the Ape, that with much paine</br>Hee could himselfe in quiet moode containe.

But Reynald thus reply'd.  "Well have you spoken</br>"In this behalfe, for these your words betoken</br>Your common care, which nature tyes us to,</br>Not for our selves being onely borne to doe.</br>Yet you (me seemes Sir Oxe) without such shift</br>By merit may your selfe to honour lift,</br>Seeing every where true merit hath her place</br>At least it can no where receive disgrace."

The Oxe replay'd.  "I would thy words were true</br>Would merit every where might have her due,</br>Then should I not behold unto my griefe</br>The meritorious want without reliefe.</br>But loe, Ah lasse, behold the noble Horse</br>That ev'n hath spent the utmost of his force,</br>'Gainst th' Aegle and the Dragon his proud mate</br>Who both of late made warre upon our State,</br>How oft have I beheld him with delight</br>Preparing of himselfe for bloody fight,</br>Who never fear'd what might by foes bee done</br>With Ha, ha, ha, the Battaile hath begun,</br>The eyes of Gorgon burning in his head</br>With feare hath made his fainting foes halfe dead.</br>And proudly prauncing with a side-long pace</br>Lifting his fetlockes up with nimble grace,</br>All Rainbow-like hee bore his crest deckt necke</br>In proud contempt of any Counterchecke,</br>Then on the hard ground having made some proofe</br>Of the strong battery of his hardy hoofe,</br>With nimble Capers in a stately daunce</br>He towards the battaile bold would proudly praunce,</br>And being come in sight of th' Armed foes</br>Hee snuffes, he puffes, he Boggles, snoarts and blowes,</br>And neighing with shrill voyce, hee seemes to cry</br>And call for Combate with the Enemy.</br>Then like the Lightning from the Easterne ayre</br>Or swiftest whirlewind, in his fierce repayre</br>To flie 'mongst thickest troupes he hath bin seene</br>To lose his life, or worthy Conquest winne,</br>Where in a moment, from the dusty ground</br>Into the ayre hee up would lightly bound,</br>And falling downe againe, with sinewie shankes</br>Would beat and batter downe the thickest rankes,</br>From whence he oftentimes (though wounded) came</br>With Conquests high renowne, and endlesse fame.</br>But now where is the meed of his true merit?</br>Who now yeelds comfort to his fainting spirit?</br>Live not the sonnes of Mars in every eye</br>The perfect maps of Ragged beggery,</br>As often as their wounds they doe behold</br>The which they tooke their Countries cause t' uphold,</br>Their eyes, lippes, hands, and harts, to heav'n doe goe,</br>Wishing pale Death to end their helplesse woe;</br>Which being deny'd dire need doth them constraine</br>To doe the thing their soules did once disdaine,</br>Ev'n Begger-like one single Mite to crave</br>Poore life within his halfe-starv'd house, to save."</br>This said, the Foxe forthwith with winking eyne</br>To th' Ape was decreed gave privie signe.

Who stepping forth with countenance fell, thus spake</br>"Friend Foxe quoth hee, your witnesse heere I take</br>Of their disloyall words, which intimate</br>Their treacherous thoughts against the Prince and State.

"Sure sayd the Fox, their speeches doe import</br>As much as Treason, if 'twere heard in Court,</br>But they perchance will happily repent</br>Let me disswade you then from your intent,</br>For if the Councell of the Lyon dread</br>Bee certified of this, they are but dead.</br>They shall compound with you, and 'twere not good</br>For you to seeke the shedding of their blood."</br>With this intent the Fox thus spake, as hee</br>That thought thereby to gaine some golden fee</br>To stop their mouths, but both the Sheepe and Oxe,</br>Perceiving well the knavery of the Foxe,</br>As they that guiltlesse were, withouten doubt</br>Defied both Fox and Ape with courage stout.

The Ape perceiving this swore by his head</br>For those their words, they should ere long be dead.</br>And so enrag'd to Court he went againe</br>With Reynald his slye copesmate to complaine.</br>Where when they came, such Treason they detect</br>Which 'gainst the Oxe and Sheepe they did object,</br>That with swift summoning they cyted were</br>Before the Lyons Councell to appeare.</br>The time was set, and loe those Royall Peeres</br>That on their backes the Forrests burthen beares</br>Jove-like in Councell, each one tooke his place</br>To give their judgement in so weightie a case.</br>The Guard attendant on the Forrest King</br>The Oxe and Sheepe, unto the Barre did bring;</br>Then with shrill voyce, the Cryer 'mongst them all</br>A generall silence through the Court did call,</br>Which every where advisefull audience bred</br>While thus th' Inditement by the Clerke was read.

"Come forth Sir Oxe (sayd hee) stand at the Barre,</br>And thou Sir Sheepe, yee both Indited are</br>For Treason, 'gainst the Lyon our dread King</br>Which th' Ape and Foxe of late to light did bring,</br>And for lewd Speech us'd 'mongst the vulgar sort</br>Seeking thereby for to defame the Court;</br>Intitling those by names of Beggers base,</br>That for desert are in the Princes grace:</br>And which is worse for your disloyal hate</br>And treasonable grudging 'gainst the state</br>Of all which treasons worthy vengefull wreake</br>If you be guilty or not guilty speake?"

To this, the Oxe not guilty did reply</br>And therewithall he craved liberty</br>With humble suite that he might answer shape</br>'Gainst this Inditement of the Fox and Ape,</br>Which granted after humble reverence made</br>Unto the bench, these words he boldly sayd.</br>"Right honored Lords, Peeres of a peerelesse King</br>From whose sole care our common good doth spring,</br>The greatest part of treason urged heere</br>As by the inditement read may well appeare</br>Consists in words which as our foes report</br>By us were spoken 'gainst the King and Court:</br>But daigne dread Lords, to marke what we have sayd</br>And what construction thereof they have made;</br>Naught 'gainst the Court or Courtier did wee say</br>But 'gainst such Vice as in the Court beares sway.</br>The Court where wonnes so many a Joviall spring</br>Made famous by the influence of a noble King,</br>As like Joves Pallace 'bove the starry skye,</br>Rather to bee admir'd, then judg'd with mortall eye;</br>Yet as in a Paradise of sweet delight</br>With rarest Fruits and fairest Flowers bedight,</br>Ne'rethelesse the care the cunning Gardener takes</br>His hookes, his sythes, his pickaxe, spade and rakes,</br>Some fruitlesse weeds are growing on the ground:</br>So in our Kings owne Pallace may bee found</br>Amongst the number that praise-worthy bee</br>Some wicked Beasts of more then base degree.</br>And 'gainst such Vice, as they doe there support</br>Wee did inveigh; and not against the Court:</br>Ne did we say, that such have Beggers bin</br>That by desert doe Grace or favour winne:</br>But such as dayly use with restlesse gaping</br>With cloaked falsehood and with tedious begging</br>Of our dread Soveraignes golden guifts to crave</br>Although no merit in themselves they have;</br>This is the summe in briefe of what we spake</br>And this is it which they would treason make."</br>This said, dumbe silence for a certaine space</br>Did shut the lips of all that were in place</br>Till at the last, that great Heroe rose</br>Who of the Forrests treasure doth dispose</br>The noble Elephant, who as he stood</br>From his sweet mouth powr'd forth a fluent flood</br>Of honied eloquence, which wanting skill</br>If I expresse the same, soone should I spill</br>With sharpe invective, first against that sort</br>Of hungry Beggers that frequent the Court</br>Hee did inveigh, then by his powerfull wit</br>Hee shewed since he in Counsels seat did sit;</br>How many private States had changed bin</br>Which by observance he had mark't and seene,</br>Supplanted all by cousenage of the Ape</br>Or by some falsehood which the Fox did shape.</br>Then 'gainst the Ape, his speech he gan to frame</br>Hee shew'd what Beast he was and whence he came</br>How Jove at first, for his deceiptfull guile</br>Made him, of man a Beast, and in that Isle</br>Call'd Ape Isle of his name, alone him put</br>And how his taile at length for craft was cut.</br>Then question'd he the Fox, to know if hee</br>Against the Oxe and Sheepe would witnes bee</br>And what true depositions he could bring</br>That they intended treason 'gainst the King.</br>The Fox though halfe amaz'd with suddaine feare</br>To heare such words from such a mighty Peere,</br>Yet that his witnes might seeme more t' have troth</br>Hee did unbidden seeke to take his oath.</br>The booke was brought; but loe the Eternall Jove</br>Who by his power protecteth from above</br>The cause of Innocence, with dreadfull frowne</br>From Heav'ns high Palace cast his count'nance downe</br>And as the Foxe his oath began to take</br>As Jove but stirr'd, hee made Olympus shake,</br>And thundring horribly above the skie,</br>Through the ayre hee made a sulphurie flash to she,</br>Which fell upon the Foxe, for his foule sinne;</br>And for his judgement strange, so syng'd his skinne</br>That since, All Foxes smell of it and beare</br>A synged colour ever in their haire.</br>This suddaine change, amaz'd the standers by</br>Who all with one consent, gan glorifie</br>The name of Jove, and 's judgement forthwith gave</br>Against the Ape, who now no wit could save</br>From punishment; For 'bout the Forrest wide</br>They whipt him well, and soundly lasht his hide.
So did the Begger bluntly end his Tale,</br>In which (your pardon I crave) if ought I faile</br>And if in reading, Beggerly you hold it,</br>Dislike it not, because a Begger told it.</br>
